00001 #include "Utils All.h"
00002 #include "Language Defines.h"

00005 #ifdef POLISH
00006 
00007 /*
00008 
00009 ******************************************************************************************************
00010 **                                  IMPORTANT TRANSLATION NOTES                                     **
00011 ******************************************************************************************************
00012 
00013 GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
00014 - Always be aware that foreign strings should be of equal or shorter length than the English equivalent.  
00015       I know that this is difficult to do on many occasions due to the nature of foreign languages when 
00016       compared to English.  By doing so, this will greatly reduce the amount of work on both sides.  In 
00017       most cases (but not all), JA2 interfaces were designed with just enough space to fit the English word.  
00018       The general rule is if the string is very short (less than 10 characters), then it's short because of 
00019       interface limitations.  On the other hand, full sentences commonly have little limitations for length.  
00020       Strings in between are a little dicey.
00021 - Never translate a string to appear on multiple lines.  All strings L"This is a really long string...", 
00022       must fit on a single line no matter how long the string is.  All strings start with L" and end with ",
00023 - Never remove any extra spaces in strings.  In addition, all strings containing multiple sentences only 
00024       have one space after a period, which is different than standard typing convention.  Never modify sections 
00025       of strings contain combinations of % characters.  These are special format characters and are always 
00026       used in conjunction with other characters.  For example, %s means string, and is commonly used for names,
00027       locations, items, etc.  %d is used for numbers.  %c%d is a character and a number (such as A9).  
00028       %% is how a single % character is built.  There are countless types, but strings containing these 
00029       special characters are usually commented to explain what they mean.  If it isn't commented, then 
00030       if you can't figure out the context, then feel free to ask SirTech.
00031 - Comments are always started with // Anything following these two characters on the same line are 
00032       considered to be comments.  Do not translate comments.  Comments are always applied to the following 
00033       string(s) on the next line(s), unless the comment is on the same line as a string.  
00034 - All new comments made by SirTech will use "//@@@ comment" (without the quotes) notation.  By searching 
00035       for @@@ everytime you recieve a new version, it will simplify your task and identify special instructions.
00036   Commonly, these types of comments will be used to ask you to abbreviate a string.  Please leave the 
00037       comments intact, and SirTech will remove them once the translation for that particular area is resolved.
00038 - If you have a problem or question with translating certain strings, please use "//!!! comment" 
00039       (without the quotes).  The syntax is important, and should be identical to the comments used with @@@ 
00040       symbols.  SirTech will search for !!! to look for your problems and questions.  This is a more 
00041       efficient method than detailing questions in email, so try to do this whenever possible.
00042 
00043 
00044       
00045 FAST HELP TEXT -- Explains how the syntax of fast help text works.
00046 **************
00047 
00048 1) BOLDED LETTERS
00049       The popup help text system supports special characters to specify the hot key(s) for a button.  
00050       Anytime you see a '|' symbol within the help text string, that means the following key is assigned
00051       to activate the action which is usually a button.  
00052 
00053       EX:  L"|Map Screen" 
00054 
00055       This means the 'M' is the hotkey.  In the game, when somebody hits the 'M' key, it activates that
00056       button.  When translating the text to another language, it is best to attempt to choose a word that
00057       uses 'M'.  If you can't always find a match, then the best thing to do is append the 'M' at the end
00058       of the string in this format:
00059 
00060       EX:  L"Ecran De Carte (|M)"  (this is the French translation)
00061 
00062       Other examples are used multiple times, like the Esc key  or "|E|s|c" or Space -> (|S|p|a|c|j|a)
00063 
00064 2) NEWLINE
00065   Any place you see a \n within the string, you are looking at another string that is part of the fast help
00066       text system.  \n notation doesn't need to be precisely placed within that string, but whereever you wish 
00067       to start a new line. 
00068 
00069       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions,\nand allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00070 
00071       Would appear as:
00072 
00073                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00074                         and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00075 
00076       NOTE:  It is important that you don't pad the characters adjacent to the \n with spaces.  If we did this
00077              in the above example, we would see
00078 
00079       WRONG WAY -- spaces before and after the \n
00080       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions, \n and allows you to re-enter them manually." 
00081 
00082       Would appear as: (the second line is moved in a character)
00083             
00084                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00085                          and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00086 
00087 
00088 @@@ NOTATION
00089 ************
00090 
00091       Throughout the text files, you'll find an assortment of comments.  Comments are used to describe the
00092       text to make translation easier, but comments don't need to be translated.  A good thing is to search for
00093       "@@@" after receiving new version of the text file, and address the special notes in this manner.  
00094 
00095 !!! NOTATION
00096 ************
00097 
00098       As described above, the "!!!" notation should be used by you to ask questions and address problems as
00099       SirTech uses the "@@@" notation.
00100 
00101 */
00102
